result_equations.equation: F_c = m v^2/r = m omega^2 r

explanation: Centripetal force is the net force directed toward the center of curvature that causes an object to follow a curved path. For uniform circular motion, this force is constant in magnitude but continuously changes direction, providing the centripetal acceleration needed to maintain circular motion.

definitions.definition: Mass of the object in circular motion.
Angular velocity of the circular motion.

assumptions.text: The motion is circular with constant radius r.
For uniform circular motion, the speed is constant.
The circular motion occurs in a plane with constant radius.
Newton's second law applies in the radial direction.

derivation.equation: vec r(t) = r (cos(omega t) hat i + sin(omega t) hat j)
vec v(t) = d vec r/dt = r omega (-sin(omega t) hat i + cos(omega t) hat j)
vec a(t) = d vec v/dt = -r omega^2 (cos(omega t) hat i + sin(omega t) hat j)
F_c = m a_c = m v^2/r = m omega^2 r

derivation_explanation.text: Express position vector for uniform circular motion in Cartesian coordinates.
Find velocity by taking the time derivative of position.
The magnitude of velocity is constant and equals rω.
Find acceleration by taking the time derivative of velocity.
The acceleration vector points radially inward, opposite to position.
The magnitude of centripetal acceleration in terms of v and ω.
Apply Newton's second law to find the required centripetal force.

code: t, r, omega, m, v = sp.symbols('t r omega m v', positive=True)

limitations: May need modifications for variable radius
Does not account for tangential forces

historical_context.importance: Fundamental concept in circular motion, crucial for orbital mechanics and rotating systems
